00026 #include "ord/ordTypes.h"

00028 // VMI area includes

00034 
00036 // SIMULATOR CONTROL
00038 
00039 //
00040 // Explicitly suspend simulation of the passed processor on completion of the
00041 // current simulated instruction to allow other processors in a multiprocessor
00042 // simulation to run. Simulation of the processor will restart when all other
00043 // runnable processors have executed.
00044 //
00045 void vmirtYield(vmiProcessorP processor);
00046 
00047 //
00048 // Halt the passed processor on completion of the current simulated instruction.
00049 // The processor will remain halted until restarted by a call to
00050 // vmirtRestartNext or vmirtRestartNow.
00051 //
00052 void vmirtHalt(vmiProcessorP processor);
00053 
00054 //
00055 // Interrupt simulation of the passed processor on completion of the current
00056 // simulated instruction and return from simulator invocation.
00057 //
00058 void vmirtInterrupt(vmiProcessorP processor);
00059 
00060 //
00061 // Immediately end simulation of the passed processor. Simulation of other
00062 // processors in a multiprocessor platform will continue.
00063 //
00064 void vmirtExit(vmiProcessorP processor);
00065 
00066 //
00067 // Immediately end simulation of any current processor. Simulation of other
00068 // processors in a multiprocessor platform will also end on completion of the
00069 // current time slice.
00070 //
00071 void vmirtFinish(Int32 status);
00072 
00073 //
00074 // Interrupt simulation and enter debugger shell (if Imperas debugger attached).
00075 // If Imperas debugger is not attached, exit simulation.
00076 //
00077 void vmirtStop(void);
00078 
00079 //
00080 // Indicate that following code should be executed atomically in a
00081 // multiprocessor simulation
00082 //
00083 void vmirtAtomic(void);
00084 
00085 //
00086 // Halt the passed processor, aborting any currently-executing instruction. The
00087 // processor will remain halted until restarted by a call to vmirtRestartNext or
00088 // vmirtRestartNow. On restart, re-execute the currently-executing instruction.
00089 //
00090 void vmirtBlock(vmiProcessorP processor);
00091 
00092 //
00093 // Is the passed processor halted?
00094 //
00095 Bool vmirtIsHalted(vmiProcessorP processor);
00096 
00097 //
00098 // Restart a previously-halted processor at the start of the next time slice
00099 //
00100 void vmirtRestartNext(vmiProcessorP processor);
00101 
00102 //
00103 // Restart a previously-halted processor immediately
00104 //
00105 void vmirtRestartNow(vmiProcessorP processor);
00106 
00107 //
00108 // Turn on instruction tracing after a given number of instructions
00109 //
00110 void vmirtTraceOnAfter(vmiProcessorP processor, Uns64 iDelta);
00111 
00112 //
00113 // Turn off instruction tracing after a given number of instructions
00114 //
00115 void vmirtTraceOffAfter(vmiProcessorP processor, Uns64 iDelta);
00116 
00117 
00119 // INTERRUPTS
00121 
00122 //
00123 // Process any pending interrupts. This routine should be used when an interrupt
00124 // needs to be scheduled because of simulated processor state changes (e.g.
00125 // simulated processor interrupts have been enabled by some instruction and
00126 // there are pending interrupts that have now been enabled). This will interrupt
00127 // the processor after the next instruction.
00128 //
00129 void vmirtDoSynchronousInterrupt(vmiProcessorP processor);
00130 
00131 
00133 // NETS
00135 
00136 //
00137 // Find the handle for a processor net given a net port name.
00138 //
00139 Uns32 vmirtGetNetPortHandle(vmiProcessorP processor, const char *netPortName);
00140 
00141 //
00142 // Write a value to a processor net port
00143 //
00144 void vmirtWriteNetPort(vmiProcessorP processor, Uns32 handle, Uns32 value);
00145 
00146 //
00147 // Read a value from a processor net port
00148 //
00149 Uns32 vmirtReadNetPort(vmiProcessorP processor, Uns32 handle);
00150 
00151 //
00152 // Install a notifier, called when a net port changes state.
00153 // This is only for use in an intercept library. To install a notifier in a
00154 // model, use the net port specification methodology described in the VMI Run
00155 // Time Function Reference manual.
00156 //
00157 void vmirtInstallNetCallback(
00158     vmiProcessorP  processor,
00159     const char    *netPortName,
00160     vmiNetChangeFn netChangeCB,
00161     void          *userData
00162 );

00249 
00250 //
00251 // Utility function for N-byte loads from the passed address in the domain.
00252 // If 'cachedRegion' is non-NULL, it should point to a null-initialized memory
00253 // region cache that is used by the simulator to store a hint region to improve
00254 // performance when multiple accesses are made to to the same area of memory.
00255 //
00256 memMapped vmirtReadNByteDomain(
00257     memDomainP     domain,
00258     Addr           simAddress,
00259     void          *buffer,
00260     Addr           size,
00261     memRegionPP    cachedRegion,
00262     memAccessAttrs attrs
00263 );
00264 
00265 //
00266 // Utility function for N-byte loads from the passed address in the domain.
00267 // If 'cachedRegion' is non-NULL, it should point to a null-initialized memory
00268 // region cache that is used by the simulator to store a hint region to improve
00269 // performance when multiple accesses are made to to the same area of memory.
00270 // Argument 'VA' is a virtual address that will be passed as the VA argument of
00271 // any callback function of type vmiMemReadFn, vmiMemWriteFn or vmiMemWatchFn
00272 // that is activated as a result of this call.
00273 //
00274 memMapped vmirtReadNByteDomainVA(
00275     memDomainP     domain,
00276     Addr           simAddress,
00277     void          *buffer,
00278     Addr           size,
00279     memRegionPP    cachedRegion,
00280     Addr           VA,
00281     memAccessAttrs attrs
00282 );
00283 
00284 //
00285 // Utility function for N-byte stores to the passed address in the domain.
00286 // If 'cachedRegion' is non-NULL, it should point to a null-initialized memory
00287 // region cache that is used by the simulator to store a hint region to improve
00288 // performance when multiple accesses are made to to the same area of memory.
00289 //
00290 memMapped vmirtWriteNByteDomain(
00291     memDomainP     domain,
00292     Addr           simAddress,
00293     const void    *buffer,
00294     Addr           size,
00295     memRegionPP    cachedRegion,
00296     memAccessAttrs attrs
00297 );
00298 
00299 //
00300 // Utility function for N-byte stores to the passed address in the domain.
00301 // If 'cachedRegion' is non-NULL, it should point to a null-initialized memory
00302 // region cache that is used by the simulator to store a hint region to improve
00303 // performance when multiple accesses are made to to the same area of memory.
00304 // Argument 'VA' is a virtual address that will be passed as the VA argument of
00305 // any callback function of type vmiMemReadFn, vmiMemWriteFn or vmiMemWatchFn
00306 // that is activated as a result of this call.
00307 //
00308 memMapped vmirtWriteNByteDomainVA(
00309     memDomainP     domain,
00310     Addr           simAddress,
00311     const void    *buffer,
00312     Addr           size,
00313     memRegionPP    cachedRegion,
00314     Addr           VA,
00315     memAccessAttrs attrs
00316 );
00317 
00318 //
00319 // If the region can support and optimized N-byte write to address simLow,
00320 // return a native pointer to use for that write; otherwise return NULL.
00321 // This can be used in combination with the cached region maintained by
00322 // vmirtReadNByteDomain to optimist reads. 'trueAccess' indicates whether the
00323 // read is a true processor read or whether it is a simulation artifact (for
00324 // example, to model semi-hosting).
00325 //
00326 void *vmirtGetReadNByteSrc(
00327     memRegionP region,
00328     Addr       simAddress,
00329     Addr       size,
00330     Bool       trueAccess
00331 );
00332 
00333 //
00334 // If the region can support and optimized N-byte write to address simLow,
00335 // return a native pointer to use for that write; otherwise return NULL.
00336 // This can be used in combination with the cached region maintained by
00337 // vmirtWriteNByteDomain to optimize writes. 'trueAccess' indicates whether the
00338 // write is a true processor read or whether it is a simulation artifact (for
00339 // example, to model semi-hosting).
00340 //
00341 void *vmirtGetWriteNByteDst(
00342     memRegionP region,
00343     Addr       simAddress,
00344     Addr       size,
00345     Bool       trueAccess
00346 );
00347 
00348 //
00349 // Get a pointer to a NULL-terminated string in simulated memory.
00350 //
00351 const char *vmirtGetString(memDomainP domain, Addr simAddress);

00430 
00432 // PROGRAM COUNTER AND CODE DICTIONARY OPERATIONS
00434 
00435 //
00436 // Return the current program counter for a processor
00437 //
00438 Addr vmirtGetPC(vmiProcessorP processor);
00439 
00440 //
00441 // For processors without delay slots, or for a non-delay-slot instruction
00442 // of a processor with delay slots, return the processor program counter and
00443 // set 'delaySlotOffset' to zero. For a delay slot instruction, return the
00444 // program counter of the preceding jump instruction and set 'delaySlotOffset'
00445 // to the offset in bytes of the delay slot instruction.
00446 //
00447 Addr vmirtGetPCDS(vmiProcessorP processor, Uns8 *delaySlotOffset);
00448 
00449 //
00450 // Set the program counter for a processor. If vmirtSetPC is called from a
00451 // function invoked with vmirtCall the new PC becomes effective when vmirtCall'd
00452 // function returns. Any code following the vmirtCall is not executed.
00453 //
00454 void vmirtSetPC(vmiProcessorP processor, Addr newPC);
00455 
00456 //
00457 // Set the program counter and delay slot program counter for a processor. The
00458 // instruction at address 'newPC1' will be executed, after which execution will
00459 // continue at 'newPC2'. If 'slotCB' is non-null, it will be executed on
00460 // completion of the instruction at address 'newPC1'. This function is useful
00461 // when implementing processors that allow exceptions to return to delay slot
00462 // instructions.
00463 //
00464 void vmirtSetPCDS(
00465     vmiProcessorP processor,
00466     Addr          newPC1,
00467     Addr          newPC2,
00468     vmiPostSlotFn slotCB
00469 );
00470 
00471 //
00472 // Set the program counter for a processor, as for vmirtSetPC, indicating that
00473 // the control flow update is caused by an exception.
00474 //
00475 void vmirtSetPCException(vmiProcessorP processor, Addr simPC);
00476 
00477 //
00478 // Set the program counter for a processor and flush the target address from the
00479 // processor code dictionary. If vmirtSetPC is called from a function invoked
00480 // with vmirtCall the new PC becomes effective when vmirtCall'd function returns.
00481 // Any code following the vmirtCall is not executed.
00482 //
00483 void vmirtSetPCFlushTarget(vmiProcessorP processor, Addr newPC);
00484 
00485 //
00486 // Set the program counter for a processor and flush the entire processor
00487 // current code dictionary. If vmirtSetPCFlushDict is called from a function
00488 // invoked with vmirtCall the new PC becomes effective when vmirtCall'd function
00489 // returns. Any code following the vmirtCall is not executed.
00490 //
00491 void vmirtSetPCFlushDict(vmiProcessorP processor, Addr newPC);
00492 
00493 //
00494 // Flush any code block containing the passed simulated address from the
00495 // processor code dictionary
00496 //
00497 void vmirtFlushTarget(vmiProcessorP processor, Addr flushPC);
00498 
00499 //
00500 // Flush any code block containing the passed simulated address from the
00501 // processor code dictionary for the passed processor mode
00502 //
00503 void vmirtFlushTargetMode(vmiProcessorP processor, Addr flushPC, Uns32 mode);
00504 
00505 //
00506 // Flush any code block containing the passed simulated address from the
00507 // processor code dictionary for the passed processor mode, unless the block
00508 // is tagged for preservation.
00509 // If flushIfEqual is True, the block will be flushed if:
00510 //      (blockTag & tagMask) == tagValue
00511 // If flushIfEqual is False, the block will be flushed if:
00512 //      (blockTag & tagMask) != tagValue
00513 // Function vmimtTagBlock is used to mark code blocks with tags.
00514 //
00515 void vmirtFlushTargetModeTagged(
00516     vmiProcessorP processor,
00517     Addr          flushPC,
00518     Uns32         mode,
00519     vmiBlockTag   tagMask,
00520     vmiBlockTag   tagValue,
00521     Bool          flushIfEqual
00522 );
00523 
00524 //
00525 // Flush the entire current processor code dictionary
00526 //
00527 void vmirtFlushDict(vmiProcessorP processor);
00528 
00529 //
00530 // Flush all processor code dictionaries
00531 //
00532 void vmirtFlushAllDicts(vmiProcessorP processor);
00533 
00534 //
00535 // Add fetch callback on processor simulated address
00536 //
00537 Bool vmirtAddPCCallback(
00538     vmiProcessorP processor,
00539     Addr          simPC,
00540     vmiPCWatchFn  watchCB,
00541     void         *userData
00542 );
00543 
00544 //
00545 // Remove fetch callback on processor simulated address
00546 //
00547 Bool vmirtRemovePCCallback(
00548     vmiProcessorP processor,
00549     Addr          simPC,
00550     vmiPCWatchFn  watchCB,
00551     void         *userData
00552 );
00553

00556 // DICTIONARY AND BLOCK MODES
00558 
00559 //
00560 // Return the current processor dictionary index
00561 //
00562 Uns32 vmirtGetMode(vmiProcessorP processor);
00563 
00564 //
00565 // Change to the indexed processor dictionary before the next instruction
00566 // starts. The return value indicates whether dictionary switch was successful
00567 // (False implies the processor has no dictionary with the given index)
00568 //
00569 Bool vmirtSetMode(vmiProcessorP processor, Uns32 dictionaryIndex);
00570 
00571 //
00572 // Return the current processor block mask
00573 //
00574 Uns32 vmirtGetBlockMask(vmiProcessorP processor);
00575 
00576 //
00577 // Change the processor block mask before the next instruction starts - used
00578 // in combination with vmimtValidateBlockMask to facilitate implementation of
00579 // instructions that are enabled by processor mode bits
00580 //
00581 void vmirtSetBlockMask(vmiProcessorP processor, Uns32 blockMask);
00582 
00583 
00585 // INSTRUCTION COUNTING AND INTERRUPT AFTER COUNT
00587 
00588 //
00589 // Return the processor speed in nominal instructions per second
00590 //
00591 Flt64 vmirtGetProcessorIPS(vmiProcessorP processor);
00592 
00593 //
00594 // Return the number of processor instructions executed.
00595 //
00596 Uns64 vmirtGetICount(vmiProcessorP processor);
00597 
00598 //
00599 // Schedule an interrupt after iDelta instructions using the processor implicit
00600 // timer (callback specified as the icountExceptCB member of the processor
00601 // vmiIASAttr structure).
00602 //
00603 void vmirtSetICountInterrupt(vmiProcessorP processor, Uns64 iDelta);
00604 
00605 //
00606 // Clear an instruction count interrupt using the processor implicit timer
00607 //
00608 void vmirtClearICountInterrupt(vmiProcessorP processor);
00609 
00610 //
00611 // Create a new processor model timer. Argument 'scale' gives a scale factor by
00612 // which the timer will run slower than the processor MIPS rate. For example:
00613 //     scale = 1:   timer increments once every instruction.
00614 //     scale = 10:  timer increments once every 10 instructions.
00615 // A scale factor of 0 is treated as 1.
00616 //
00617 vmiModelTimerP vmirtCreateModelTimer(
00618     vmiProcessorP processor,
00619     vmiICountFn   icountCB,
00620     Uns32         scale,
00621     void         *userData
00622 );
00623 
00624 //
00625 // Create a new monotonic processor model timer. Monotonic timers behave exactly
00626 // like normal model timers except that in a multiprocessor simulation
00627 // monotonic timer values are guaranteed to present a consistent view of time
00628 // that increases monotonically.
00629 //
00630 vmiModelTimerP vmirtCreateMonotonicModelTimer(
00631     vmiProcessorP processor,
00632     vmiICountFn   icountCB,
00633     Uns32         scale,
00634     void         *userData
00635 );
00636 
00637 //
00638 // Delete a processor model timer
00639 //
00640 void vmirtDeleteModelTimer(vmiModelTimerP modelTimer);
00641 
00642 //
00643 // Set a model timer to schedule a callback after 'delta' timer ticks
00644 //
00645 void vmirtSetModelTimer(vmiModelTimerP modelTimer, Uns64 delta);
00646 
00647 //
00648 // Clear a model timer
00649 //
00650 void vmirtClearModelTimer(vmiModelTimerP modelTimer);
00651 
00652 //
00653 // Is the timer in an enabled state?
00654 //
00655 Bool vmirtIsModelTimerEnabled(vmiModelTimerP modelTimer);
00656 
00657 //
00658 // If 'ticks' is True, return the current tick count of the timer; if 'ticks' is
00659 // False, return the current instruction count of the timer.
00660 //
00661 Uns64 vmirtGetModelTimerCurrentCount(vmiModelTimerP modelTimer, Bool ticks);
00662 
00663 //
00664 // If 'ticks' is True, return the number of ticks at which the counter is
00665 // scheduled to expire; If 'ticks' is False, return the number of instructions
00666 // at which the counter is scheduled to expire. If the counter is not currently
00667 // enabled, -1 is returned.
00668 //
00669 Uns64 vmirtGetModelTimerExpiryCount(vmiModelTimerP modelTimer, Bool ticks);
00670 
00671 
00673 // BASIC MEMORY OPERATIONS
00675 
00676 //
00677 // Get the code and data endianness of a processor
00678 //
00679 memEndian vmirtGetProcessorCodeEndian(vmiProcessorP processor);
00680 memEndian vmirtGetProcessorDataEndian(vmiProcessorP processor);
00681 
00682 //
00683 // Get code domain and data domain for processor (virtual address space)
00684 //
00685 memDomainP vmirtGetProcessorCodeDomain(vmiProcessorP processor);
00686 memDomainP vmirtGetProcessorDataDomain(vmiProcessorP processor);
00687 
00688 //
00689 // Set current code domain and data domain for processor. The domain will remain
00690 // active until reset by these functions or the processor switches mode. To
00691 // permanently change the domain used for each processor mode, use functions
00692 // vmirtSetProcessorCodeDomains and vmirtSetProcessorDataDomains below
00693 //
00694 void vmirtSetProcessorCodeDomain(vmiProcessorP processor, memDomainP domain);
00695 void vmirtSetProcessorDataDomain(vmiProcessorP processor, memDomainP domain);
00696 
00697 //
00698 // Get domains associated with the externally-connected data and code busses
00699 //
00700 memDomainP vmirtGetProcessorExternalCodeDomain(vmiProcessorP processor);
00701 memDomainP vmirtGetProcessorExternalDataDomain(vmiProcessorP processor);
00702 
00703 //
00704 // Deprecated names for external domain accessors
00705 //
00706 #define vmirtGetProcessorPhysicalCodeDomain vmirtGetProcessorExternalCodeDomain
00707 #define vmirtGetProcessorPhysicalDataDomain vmirtGetProcessorExternalDataDomain
00708 
00709 //
00710 // Get domains associated with internal code and data busses (domains
00711 // registered using vmirtSetProcessorInternalCodeDomain and
00712 // vmirtSetProcessorInternalDataDomain when the processor is initialized)
00713 //
00714 memDomainP vmirtGetProcessorInternalCodeDomain(vmiProcessorP processor);
00715 memDomainP vmirtGetProcessorInternalDataDomain(vmiProcessorP processor);
00716 
00717 //
00718 // Set internal code domain and internal data domain for processor. These
00719 // functions should be called at most once, in the virtual memory constructor.
00720 // The internal code domains should be associated with an address space after
00721 // any virtual memory remapping has been performed but before any structures
00722 // such as caches. If these functions are not called, the domains associated
00723 // with externally-connected data and code busses are used.
00724 //
00725 void vmirtSetProcessorInternalCodeDomain(
00726     vmiProcessorP processor,
00727     memDomainP    domain
00728 );
00729 void vmirtSetProcessorInternalDataDomain(
00730     vmiProcessorP processor,
00731     memDomainP    domain
00732 );
00733 
00734 //
00735 // Set code and data domains to be used henceforth by the processor for code
00736 // and data accesses in each processor mode. 'domains' should be a pointer to an
00737 // array of domain pointers with one entry for each processor mode (in other
00738 // words, the same number of entries as there are dictionaries in the processor)
00739 //
00740 void vmirtSetProcessorCodeDomains(vmiProcessorP processor, memDomainPP domains);
00741 void vmirtSetProcessorDataDomains(vmiProcessorP processor, memDomainPP domains);
00742 
00743 //
00744 // Is the code domain address executable?
00745 //
00746 Bool vmirtIsExecutable(vmiProcessorP processor, Addr simPC);
00747 
00748 //
00749 // Create a new memory domain addressable with addresses of the passed width
00750 //
00751 memDomainP vmirtNewDomain(const char *name, Uns8 addressBits);
00752 
00753 //
00754 // Get address width for the domain
00755 //
00756 Uns8 vmirtGetDomainAddressBits(memDomainP domain);
00757 
00758 //
00759 // Return access permissions for the passed domain address
00760 //
00761 memPriv vmirtGetDomainPrivileges(memDomainP domain, Addr simAddr);
00762 
00763 //
00764 // Return an enumeration describing whether the address range lowAddr:highAddr
00765 // is mapped in the domain - it can be either unmapped (MEM_MAP_NONE), partially
00766 // mapped (MEM_MAP_PART) or fully mapped (MEM_MAP_FULL)
00767 //
00768 memMapped vmirtGetDomainMapped(memDomainP domain, Addr lowAddr, Addr highAddr);
00769 
00770 //
00771 // Define an alias of a memory region in the physical domain within the
00772 // virtual domain. The region to be aliased extends from 'physicalLowAddr' to
00773 // 'physicalHighAddr' within the physical domain and should be located at
00774 // 'virtualLowAddr' in the virtual domain.
00775 //
00776 Bool vmirtAliasMemory(
00777     memDomainP physicalDomain,
00778     memDomainP virtualDomain,
00779     Addr       physicalLowAddr,
00780     Addr       physicalHighAddr,
00781     Addr       virtualLowAddr,
00782     memMRUSetP mruSet
00783 );
00784 
00785 //
00786 // Remove a previously-defined alias mapping of a region in the virtual domain
00787 // (see vmirtAliasMemory and vmirtAliasMemoryVM above).
00788 //
00789 Bool vmirtUnaliasMemory(
00790     memDomainP virtualDomain,
00791     Addr       virtualLowAddr,
00792     Addr       virtualHighAddr
00793 );
00794 
00795 //
00796 // Given an address in a virtual domain, set by-ref argument 'physicalDomain' to
00797 // the memory domain to which that address is ultimately resolved and return
00798 // the simulated address in that ultimate physical domain. If the address is not
00799 // mapped, the original address is returned and argument 'physicalDomain' is
00800 // set to NULL. If 'cachedRegion' is non-NULL, it should point to a
00801 // null-initialized memory region cache that is used by the simulator to store a
00802 // hint region to improve performance when multiple accesses are made to to the
00803 // same area of memory.
00804 //
00805 Addr vmirtMapVAToPA(
00806     memDomainP  virtualDomain,
00807     Addr        virtualAddr,
00808     memDomainPP physicalDomain,
00809     memRegionPP cachedRegion
00810 );
00811 
00812 //
00813 // Given an address in 'fromDomain', map that address to 'toDomain' if possible.
00814 // Return value indicates whether mapping succeeded
00815 //
00816 Bool vmirtMapToDomain(
00817     memDomainP toDomain,
00818     memDomainP fromDomain,
00819     Addr      *simAddrP
00820 );
00821 
00822 //
00823 // Change memory access privileges on the region from 'lowAddr' to 'highAddr'
00824 // in the domain.
00825 //
00826 Bool vmirtProtectMemory(
00827     memDomainP    domain,
00828     Addr          lowAddr,
00829     Addr          highAddr,
00830     memPriv       privilege,
00831     memPrivAction action
00832 );
00833 
00834 //
00835 // Map the simulated address range in the domain to use the passed native memory
00836 // for underlying storage
00837 //
00838 Bool vmirtMapNativeMemory(
00839     memDomainP domain,
00840     Addr       lowAddr,
00841     Addr       highAddr,
00842     void      *memory
00843 );
00844 
00845 //
00846 // Map the (previously unmapped) simulated address range in the domain as
00847 // simulated memory
00848 //
00849 Bool vmirtMapMemory(
00850     memDomainP domain,
00851     Addr       lowAddr,
00852     Addr       highAddr,
00853     memType    type
00854 );
00855 
00856 //
00857 // Map the (previously unmapped) simulated address range in the domain to use
00858 // the passed callbacks for read and write
00859 //
00860 Bool vmirtMapCallbacks(
00861     memDomainP    domain,
00862     Addr          lowAddr,
00863     Addr          highAddr,
00864     vmiMemReadFn  readCB,
00865     vmiMemWriteFn writeCB,
00866     void         *userData
00867 );
00868 
00869 //
00870 // Modify load/store addresses when loads and stores are applied to the given
00871 // domain so that all bits above the indicated top address bit are either set
00872 // to 0, set to 1, or sign-extended from the next lower bit.
00873 // This function affects the behavior of loads and stores only - to modify the
00874 // behavior of instruction fetches in a similar way, use vmimtSetAddressMask.
00875 //
00876 void vmirtSetLoadStoreMask(
00877     memDomainP   domain,
00878     Uns32        topBit,
00879     memLSMAction zeroAction,
00880     memLSMAction oneAction
00881 );
00882 
00883 //
00884 // Emit debug information describing all regions in the passed domain
00885 //
00886 void vmirtDebugDomain(memDomainP domain);
00887 
00888 
00890 // ASID-BASED VIRTUAL MEMORY MANAGEMENT
00892 
00893 //
00894 // Set processor current ASID - this affects accessibility of pages mapped with
00895 // vmirtAliasMemoryVM
00896 //
00897 void vmirtSetProcessorASID(vmiProcessorP processor, Uns32 ASID);
00898 
00899 //
00900 // Get processor current ASID
00901 //
00902 Uns32 vmirtGetProcessorASID(vmiProcessorP processor);
00903 
00904 //
00905 // Define an alias of a memory region in the physical domain within the
00906 // virtual domain, specifically for modeling paged virtual memory. Domain,
00907 // address and mruSet set arguments are as for vmirtAliasMemory above.
00908 // 'privilege' specifies the protections that should be applied to the mapped
00909 // page. If 'ASIDMaskOrG' is True, the mapping applies to all processor ASIDs;
00910 // otherwise, if 'ASIDMaskOrG' is False, 'ASID' specifies the particular ASID
00911 // for which the mapping applies; otherwise, 'ASIDMaskOrG' specifies a *mask*
00912 // selecting bits that must match the processor ASID for the page to match (see
00913 // also vmirtUnaliasMemoryVM and vmirtSetProcessorASID)
00914 //
00915 Bool vmirtAliasMemoryVM(
00916     memDomainP physicalDomain,
00917     memDomainP virtualDomain,
00918     Addr       physicalLowAddr,
00919     Addr       physicalHighAddr,
00920     Addr       virtualLowAddr,
00921     memMRUSetP mruSet,
00922     memPriv    privilege,
00923     Uns32      ASIDMaskOrG,
00924     Uns32      ASID
00925 );
00926 
00927 //
00928 // Remove a previously-defined alias mapping of a region in the virtual
00929 // domain. If 'ASIDMaskOrG' is True, only a matching global mapping is removed;
00930 // otherwise, if 'ASIDMaskOrG' is False, 'ASID' specifies the particular ASID
00931 // for which the mapping should be removed; otherwise, 'ASIDMaskOrG' specifies a
00932 // *mask* selecting bits that must match the ASID for the mapping to be removed
00933 // (see also vmirtAliasMemoryVM and vmirtSetProcessorASID)
00934 //
00935 Bool vmirtUnaliasMemoryVM(
00936     memDomainP virtualDomain,
00937     Addr       virtualLowAddr,
00938     Addr       virtualHighAddr,
00939     Uns32      ASIDMaskOrG,
00940     Uns32      ASID
00941 );
00942 
00943 //
00944 // Return an enumeration value indicating whether any address in the range is
00945 // ASID-mapped in the domain with the passed ASID. Return values are:
00946 //    ASID_MAP_NONE:        address not mapped with the passed ASID
00947 //    ASID_MAP_INACTIVE:    address mapped with the passed ASID but not used
00948 //                          since the last ASID switch in the domain
00949 //    ASID_MAP_ACTIVE:      address mapped with the passed ASID and used since
00950 //                          the last ASID switch in the domain
00951 //
00952 memMappedASID vmirtGetDomainMappedASID(
00953     memDomainP domain,
00954     Addr       lowAddr,
00955     Addr       highAddr,
00956     Uns32      ASID
00957 );
00958 
00959 //
00960 // Return a state table object for management of a TLB with the passed number
00961 // of entries. When indexed by the current state, the state table should give
00962 // the next state.
00963 //
00964 const Uns32 *vmirtGetMRUStateTable(Uns32 numEntries, Uns32 entryIndex);
00965 
00966 //
00967 // Return the entry index for the passed position in the state. Position 0 will
00968 // return the MRU entry index, and position numEntries-1 will return the LRU
00969 // entry index.
00970 //
00971 Uns8 vmirtGetNthStateIndex(Uns32 numEntries, Uns32 state, Uns32 position);
00972

01537 //
01538 // Create a new entry with the passed address range in the address range table.
01539 // The entry must not overlap any existing entries; if it does, the function
01540 // returns NULL.
01541 //
01542 vmiRangeEntryP vmirtInsertRangeEntry(
01543     vmiRangeTablePP table,
01544     Addr            low,
01545     Addr            high,
01546     Uns64           userData
01547 );
01548 
01549 //
01550 // Remove the passed entry from the address range table and delete it.
01551 //
01552 void vmirtRemoveRangeEntry(vmiRangeTablePP table, vmiRangeEntryP entry);
01553 
01554 //
01555 // Find the first entry in table that overlaps the range low:high. This function
01556 // initiates a delete-safe iterator in which subsequent entries can be found
01557 // using vmirtGetNextRangeEntry.
01558 //
01559 vmiRangeEntryP vmirtGetFirstRangeEntry(
01560     vmiRangeTablePP table,
01561     Addr            low,
01562     Addr            high
01563 );
01564 
01565 //
01566 // Find the next entry in table that overlaps the range low:high.
01567 //
01568 vmiRangeEntryP vmirtGetNextRangeEntry(
01569     vmiRangeTablePP table,
01570     Addr            low,
01571     Addr            high
01572 );
01573 
01574 //
01575 // Return the low address of the range entry
01576 //
01577 Addr vmirtGetRangeEntryLow(vmiRangeEntryP entry);
01578 
01579 //
01580 // Return the high address of the range entry
01581 //
01582 Addr vmirtGetRangeEntryHigh(vmiRangeEntryP entry);
01583 
01584 //
01585 // Return the userData of the range entry
01586 //
01587 Uns64 vmirtGetRangeEntryUserData(vmiRangeEntryP entry);
01588 
01589 //
01590 // Set the userData of the range entry
01591 //
01592 void vmirtSetRangeEntryUserData(vmiRangeEntryP entry, Uns64 userData);

01638 // COMMAND INTERPRETER INTEGRATION
01640 
01641 //
01642 // Add a command for the passed processor. If the defined command
01643 // is used, commandCB will be called with any supplied arguments.
01644 //
01645 vmiCommandP vmirtAddCommand(
01646     vmiProcessorP   processor,
01647     const char     *name,
01648     const char     *exampleArguments,
01649     vmirtCommandFn  commandCB,
01650     vmiCommandAttrs attrs
01651 );
01652 
01653 //
01654 // Add a command with command parser for the passed processor.
01655 // command arguments will be parsed according to arguments specified by
01656 // vmirtAddArg (see below)
01657 // In addition to the arguments specified using vmirtAddArg, the flags
01658 // -get is recognized.
01659 // If attrs contains the bit VMI_CT_HELP, then -help is recognized.
01660 // If the defined command is used, commandCB will be called with the
01661 // arguments parsed into an argValue array. The array does not
01662 // persist after the call.
01663 //
01664 vmiCommandP vmirtAddCommandParse(
01665     vmiProcessorP       processor,
01666     const char         *name,
01667     const char         *exampleArguments,
01668     vmirtCommandParseFn commandCB,
01669     vmiCommandAttrs     attrs
01670 );
01671 
01672 //
01673 // Add an argument to a command parser. If the command is called with
01674 // an argument matching the given name, it will be parsed.
01675 // If ptr is non-null, its value will be updated by the value parsed.
01676 // Note that if ptr  is pointing to a string,
01677 // the old string will be free()'d before a new string is malloc()'d
01678 //
01679 vmiArgP vmirtAddArg(
01680     vmiCommandP     command,
01681     const char     *name,
01682     const char     *help,
01683     vmiArgType      type,
01684     vmiArgAttrs     attrs,
01685     Bool            mandatory,
01686     void           *ptr
01687 );
01688 
01689 //
01690 // Add an value name to an enumerated type argument to a command parser.
01691 //
01692 void vmirtAddArgEnum(
01693     vmiArgP         argument, // the argument returned by vmirtAddArg
01694     const char     *name,     // name of enumeration
01695     const char     *help,     // not used
01696     Uns32           value     // not used
01697 );
01698 
01699 //
01700 // Find an argument value in the argument value array passed to
01701 // the vmirtCommandParseFn()
01702 //
01703 vmiArgValueP vmirtFindArgValue(Uns32 argc, vmiArgValue argv[], const char *name);
01704

01961 // SAVE / RESTORE SUPPORT ROUTINES
01963 
01964 //
01965 // Macros for save/restore of processor registers
01966 //
01967 #define VMIRT_SAVE_REG(_CXT, _NAME, _REG) \
01968     vmirtSave(_CXT, _NAME, _REG, sizeof(*(_REG)))
01969 #define VMIRT_RESTORE_REG(_CXT, _NAME, _REG) \
01970     vmirtRestore(_CXT, _NAME, _REG, sizeof(*(_REG)))
01971 
01972 //
01973 // Macros for save/restore of processor fields
01974 //
01975 #define VMIRT_SAVE_FIELD(_CXT, _PROCESSOR, _FIELD) \
01976     VMIRT_SAVE_REG(_CXT, #_FIELD, &(_PROCESSOR)->_FIELD)
01977 #define VMIRT_RESTORE_FIELD(_CXT, _PROCESSOR, _FIELD) \
01978     VMIRT_RESTORE_REG(_CXT, #_FIELD, &(_PROCESSOR)->_FIELD)
01979 
01980 //
01981 // Save a named value using the active save context
01982 //
01983 vmiSaveRestoreStatus vmirtSave(
01984     vmiSaveContextP cxt,
01985     const char     *name,
01986     const void     *value,
01987     Uns32           bytes
01988 );
01989 
01990 //
01991 // Restore a named value using the active restore context
01992 //
01993 vmiSaveRestoreStatus vmirtRestore(
01994     vmiRestoreContextP cxt,
01995     const char        *name,
01996     void              *value,
01997     Uns32              bytes
01998 );
01999 
02000 //
02001 // Save a list element using the active save context. Pass NULL to indicate the
02002 // last element of the list
02003 //
02004 vmiSaveRestoreStatus vmirtSaveElement(
02005     vmiSaveContextP cxt,
02006     const char     *elementName,
02007     const char     *endName,
02008     const void     *value,
02009     Uns32           bytes
02010 );
02011 
02012 //
02013 // Restore a list element using the active restore context. The return value
02014 // is SRS_OK if an element is successfully restored, or SRS_END_LIST if the
02015 // list terminator has been read.
02016 //
02017 vmiSaveRestoreStatus vmirtRestoreElement(
02018     vmiRestoreContextP cxt,
02019     const char        *elementName,
02020     const char        *endName,
02021     void              *value,
02022     Uns32              bytes
02023 );
02024
